question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
We are concerned with the continuity of \(f\) only at \(x=1\), though we need not be concerned about whether \(f(1)\) is defined or not, since its polynomial’pieces’ are defined on \((-\infty, \infty)\). It remains to find a \(c\) such that \(\lim_{x \to 1} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = f(1)\).

  • By the definition of \(\displaystyle f(x)\) we have \(f(1) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} cx^2 + 3 = c+3\).

  • Furthermore, \(\lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^-} 2x^3 - c = 2-c\).

Hence we need to find a \(\displaystyle c\) such that \(\displaystyle 2 - c = c + 3\). It follows that the value \(\displaystyle c\) that makes \(\displaystyle f(x)\) continuous on \((-\infty, \infty)\) is \(c = {\color{blue}\frac{-1}{2}}\).
